trans-unit.source: How to use AMQP 1.0 with the .NET Service Bus API | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use AMQP 1.0 with the .NET Service Bus API | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Advanced Message Queuing Protodol (AMQP) 1.0 with the Azure .NET Service Bus API.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Advanced Message Queuing Protodol (AMQP) 1.0 with the Azure .NET Service Bus API.

trans-unit.source: The Advanced Message Queuing Protocol (AMQP) 1.0 is an efficient, reliable, wire-level messaging protocol that you can use to build robust, cross-platform, messaging applications.
trans-unit.target: The Advanced Message Queuing Protocol (AMQP) 1.0 is an efficient, reliable, wire-level messaging protocol that you can use to build robust, cross-platform, messaging applications.

trans-unit.source: Support for AMQP 1.0 in Service Bus means that you can use the queuing and publish/subscribe brokered messaging features from a range of platforms using an efficient binary protocol.
trans-unit.target: Support for AMQP 1.0 in Service Bus means that you can use the queuing and publish/subscribe brokered messaging features from a range of platforms using an efficient binary protocol.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, you can build applications comprised of components built using a mix of languages, frameworks, and operating systems.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, you can build applications comprised of components built using a mix of languages, frameworks, and operating systems.

trans-unit.source: This how-to guide explains how to use the Service Bus brokered messaging features (queues and publish/subscribe topics) from .NET applications using the Service Bus .NET API.
trans-unit.target: This how-to guide explains how to use the Service Bus brokered messaging features (queues and publish/subscribe topics) from .NET applications using the Service Bus .NET API.

trans-unit.source: There is a companion how-to guide that explains how to do the same using the standard Java Message Service (JMS) API.
trans-unit.target: There is a companion how-to guide that explains how to do the same using the standard Java Message Service (JMS) API.

trans-unit.source: You can use these two guides together to learn about cross-platform messaging using AMQP 1.0.
trans-unit.target: You can use these two guides together to learn about cross-platform messaging using AMQP 1.0.

trans-unit.source: This guide assumes that you already have a Service Bus namespace containing a queue named "queue1."
trans-unit.target: This guide assumes that you already have a Service Bus namespace containing a queue named "queue1."

trans-unit.source: If you do not, then you can create the namespace and queue using the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you do not, then you can create the namespace and queue using the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to create Service Bus namespaces and queues, see the How-To Guide titled "<linkText>How to Use Service Bus Queues.</linkText><title></title>"
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to create Service Bus namespaces and queues, see the How-To Guide titled "<linkText>How to Use Service Bus Queues.</linkText><title></title>"

trans-unit.source: AMQP 1.0 support is available in Service Bus SDK version 2.1 or later.
trans-unit.target: AMQP 1.0 support is available in Service Bus SDK version 2.1 or later.

trans-unit.source: You can download the latest SDK from NuGet at <linkText>http://nuget.org/packages/WindowsAzure.ServiceBus/</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can download the latest SDK from NuGet at <linkText>http://nuget.org/packages/WindowsAzure.ServiceBus/</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: By default, the Service Bus .NET client library communicates with the Service Bus service using a dedicated SOAP-based protocol.
trans-unit.target: By default, the Service Bus .NET client library communicates with the Service Bus service using a dedicated SOAP-based protocol.

trans-unit.source: To use AMQP 1.0 instead of the default protocol requires explicit configuration on the Service Bus connection string as described in the next section.
trans-unit.target: To use AMQP 1.0 instead of the default protocol requires explicit configuration on the Service Bus connection string as described in the next section.

trans-unit.source: Other than this change, application code remains basically unchanged when using AMQP 1.0.
trans-unit.target: Other than this change, application code remains basically unchanged when using AMQP 1.0.

trans-unit.source: In the current release there are a few API features that are not supported when using AMQP.
trans-unit.target: In the current release there are a few API features that are not supported when using AMQP.

trans-unit.source: These unsupported features are listed later in the section "Unsupported features and restrictions."
trans-unit.target: These unsupported features are listed later in the section "Unsupported features and restrictions."

trans-unit.source: Some of the advanced configuration settings also have a different meaning when using AMQP.
trans-unit.target: Some of the advanced configuration settings also have a different meaning when using AMQP.

trans-unit.source: None of these settings are used in this short how-to guide but more details are available in the <linkText>Service Bus AMQP 1.0 Developer's Guide</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: None of these settings are used in this short how-to guide but more details are available in the <linkText>Service Bus AMQP 1.0 Developer's Guide</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: It is recommended practice for applications to use the App.config configuration file to store settings.
trans-unit.target: It is recommended practice for applications to use the App.config configuration file to store settings.

trans-unit.source: For Service Bus applications, you can use App.config to store the Service Bus ConnectionString.
trans-unit.target: For Service Bus applications, you can use App.config to store the Service Bus ConnectionString.

trans-unit.source: This sample application also uses App.config to store the name of the Service Bus messaging entity that it uses.
trans-unit.target: This sample application also uses App.config to store the name of the Service Bus messaging entity that it uses.

trans-unit.source: A sample App.config file is shown below:
trans-unit.target: A sample App.config file is shown below:

trans-unit.source: The value of the Microsoft.ServiceBus.ConnectionString setting is the Service Bus connection string that is used to configure the connection to Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: The value of the Microsoft.ServiceBus.ConnectionString setting is the Service Bus connection string that is used to configure the connection to Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: The format is as follows:
trans-unit.target: The format is as follows:

trans-unit.source: Where [namespace] and [SAS key] are obtained from the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Where [namespace] and [SAS key] are obtained from the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>How to Use Service Bus Queues</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>How to Use Service Bus Queues</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: When using AMQP, the connection string is appended with ";TransportType=Amqp", which tells the client library to make its connection to Service Bus using AMQP 1.0.
trans-unit.target: When using AMQP, the connection string is appended with ";TransportType=Amqp", which tells the client library to make its connection to Service Bus using AMQP 1.0.

trans-unit.source: This sample application uses the EntityName setting in the appSettings section of the App.config file to configure the name of the queue with which the application exchanges messages.
trans-unit.target: This sample application uses the EntityName setting in the appSettings section of the App.config file to configure the name of the queue with which the application exchanges messages.

trans-unit.source: The following example sends and receives messages to and from a Service Bus queue.
trans-unit.target: The following example sends and receives messages to and from a Service Bus queue.

trans-unit.source: Running the application produces output of the form:
trans-unit.target: Running the application produces output of the form:

trans-unit.source: SimpleSenderReceiver.exe Press [enter] to send a message.
trans-unit.target: SimpleSenderReceiver.exe Press [enter] to send a message.

trans-unit.source: Type 'exit' + [enter] to quit.
trans-unit.target: Type 'exit' + [enter] to quit.

trans-unit.source: This guide showed how to send messages to Service Bus using .NET and also how to receive those messages using .NET.
trans-unit.target: This guide showed how to send messages to Service Bus using .NET and also how to receive those messages using .NET.

trans-unit.source: However, one of the key benefits of AMQP 1.0 is that it enables applications to be built from components written in different languages, with messages exchanged reliably and at full fidelity.
trans-unit.target: However, one of the key benefits of AMQP 1.0 is that it enables applications to be built from components written in different languages, with messages exchanged reliably and at full fidelity.

trans-unit.source: Using the sample .NET application described above and a similar Java application taken from a companion guide, <linkText>How to use the Java Message Service (JMS) API with Service Bus & AMQP 1.0</linkText><title></title>, it's possible to exchange messages between .NET and Java.
trans-unit.target: Using the sample .NET application described above and a similar Java application taken from a companion guide, <linkText>How to use the Java Message Service (JMS) API with Service Bus & AMQP 1.0</linkText><title></title>, it's possible to exchange messages between .NET and Java.

trans-unit.source: For more information about the details of cross-platform messaging using Service Bus and AMQP 1.0, see the <linkText>Service Bus AMQP 1.0 Developer's Guide</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about the details of cross-platform messaging using Service Bus and AMQP 1.0, see the <linkText>Service Bus AMQP 1.0 Developer's Guide</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To demonstrate JMS to .NET messaging:
trans-unit.target: To demonstrate JMS to .NET messaging:

trans-unit.source: Start the .NET sample application without any command-line arguments.
trans-unit.target: Start the .NET sample application without any command-line arguments.

trans-unit.source: Start the Java sample application with the "sendonly" command-line argument.
trans-unit.target: Start the Java sample application with the "sendonly" command-line argument.

trans-unit.source: In this mode, the application will not receive messages from the queue, it will only send.
trans-unit.target: In this mode, the application will not receive messages from the queue, it will only send.

trans-unit.source: Press Enter a few times in the Java application console, which will cause messages to be sent.
trans-unit.target: Press Enter a few times in the Java application console, which will cause messages to be sent.

trans-unit.source: These messages are received by the .NET application.
trans-unit.target: These messages are received by the .NET application.

trans-unit.source: java SimpleSenderReceiver sendonly Press [enter] to send a message.
trans-unit.target: java SimpleSenderReceiver sendonly Press [enter] to send a message.

trans-unit.source: Type 'exit' + [enter] to quit.
trans-unit.target: Type 'exit' + [enter] to quit.

trans-unit.source: Sent message with JMSMessageID = ID:4364096528752411591 Sent message with JMSMessageID = ID:459252991689389983 Sent message with JMSMessageID = ID:1565011046230456854 exit
trans-unit.target: Sent message with JMSMessageID = ID:4364096528752411591 Sent message with JMSMessageID = ID:459252991689389983 Sent message with JMSMessageID = ID:1565011046230456854 exit

trans-unit.source: SimpleSenderReceiver.exe Press [enter] to send a message.
trans-unit.target: SimpleSenderReceiver.exe Press [enter] to send a message.

trans-unit.source: Type 'exit' + [enter] to quit.
trans-unit.target: Type 'exit' + [enter] to quit.

trans-unit.source: Received message with MessageID = 4364096528752411591 Received message with MessageID = 459252991689389983 Received message with MessageID = 1565011046230456854 exit
trans-unit.target: Received message with MessageID = 4364096528752411591 Received message with MessageID = 459252991689389983 Received message with MessageID = 1565011046230456854 exit

trans-unit.source: To demonstrate .NET to JMS messaging:
trans-unit.target: To demonstrate .NET to JMS messaging:

trans-unit.source: Start the .NET sample application with the "sendonly" command line argument.
trans-unit.target: Start the .NET sample application with the "sendonly" command line argument.

trans-unit.source: In this mode, the application will not receive messages from the queue, it will only send.
trans-unit.target: In this mode, the application will not receive messages from the queue, it will only send.

trans-unit.source: Start the Java sample application without any command line arguments.
trans-unit.target: Start the Java sample application without any command line arguments.

trans-unit.source: Press Enter a few times in the .NET application console, which will cause messages to be sent.
trans-unit.target: Press Enter a few times in the .NET application console, which will cause messages to be sent.

trans-unit.source: These messages are received by the Java application.
trans-unit.target: These messages are received by the Java application.

trans-unit.source: SimpleSenderReceiver.exe sendonly Press [enter] to send a message.
trans-unit.target: SimpleSenderReceiver.exe sendonly Press [enter] to send a message.

trans-unit.source: Type 'exit' + [enter] to quit.
trans-unit.target: Type 'exit' + [enter] to quit.

trans-unit.target: java SimpleSenderReceiver Press [enter] to send a message.

trans-unit.source: The following features of the .NET Service Bus API are not currently supported when using AMQP:
trans-unit.target: The following features of the .NET Service Bus API are not currently supported when using AMQP:

trans-unit.source: Transactions
trans-unit.target: Transactions

trans-unit.source: Send via transfer destination
trans-unit.target: Send via transfer destination

trans-unit.source: Receive by message sequence number
trans-unit.target: Receive by message sequence number

trans-unit.source: Message and session browse
trans-unit.target: Message and session browse

trans-unit.source: Session state
trans-unit.target: Session state

trans-unit.source: Batch-based APIs
trans-unit.target: Batch-based APIs

trans-unit.source: Scaled-out receive
trans-unit.target: Scaled-out receive

trans-unit.source: Runtime manipulation of subscription rules
trans-unit.target: Runtime manipulation of subscription rules

trans-unit.source: Session lock renewal
trans-unit.target: Session lock renewal

trans-unit.source: Some minor differences in behavior
trans-unit.target: Some minor differences in behavior

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <linkText>Service Bus AMQP 1.0 Developer's Guide</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <linkText>Service Bus AMQP 1.0 Developer's Guide</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This topic includes a detailed list of unsupported APIs.
trans-unit.target: This topic includes a detailed list of unsupported APIs.

trans-unit.source: This how-to guide showed how to access the Service Bus brokered messaging features (queues and publish/subscribe topics) from .NET using AMQP 1.0 and the Service Bus .NET API.
trans-unit.target: This how-to guide showed how to access the Service Bus brokered messaging features (queues and publish/subscribe topics) from .NET using AMQP 1.0 and the Service Bus .NET API.

trans-unit.source: You can also use Service Bus AMQP 1.0 from other languages including Java, C, Python, and PHP.
trans-unit.target: You can also use Service Bus AMQP 1.0 from other languages including Java, C, Python, and PHP.

trans-unit.source: Components built using these languages can exchange messages reliably and at full fidelity using AMQP 1.0 in Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: Components built using these languages can exchange messages reliably and at full fidelity using AMQP 1.0 in Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <linkText>Service Bus AMQP 1.0 Developer's Guide</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <linkText>Service Bus AMQP 1.0 Developer's Guide</linkText><title></title>.
